question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
If $a$ and $b$ are integers such that $ab\equiv 17\pmod{20}$, then what is the remainder when $(a+10)(b+10)$ is divided by $20$?
inference:
$$ab\equiv 17\pmod{20} \Rightarrow ab-17=20k \text{ for some integer }k.$$

$$a+10\equiv a\pmod{20} \text{ and } b+10\equiv b\pmod{20} \therefore$$

$$(a+10)(b+10)\equiv ab \equiv 17\pmod{20}.$$

$$17+20k\equiv 17\pmod{20} \Rightarrow 20k\equiv 0\pmod{20} \Rightarrow k\equiv 0\pmod{20} \therefore$$

$$ab-17=20(0) \Rightarrow ab=17.$$

$$(a+10)(b+10)\equiv 17\pmod{20} \Rightarrow (a+10)(b+10)=20k+17.$$

$$(a+10)(b+10)\equiv 17\pmod{20} \Rightarrow (a+10)(b+10)\equiv 17+20(0)\pmod{20} \therefore$$ 

$$(a+10)(b+10)=17.$$

$$17\equiv \boxed{17}\pmod{20}.$$

Final Answer: $\boxed{17}.$ I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
We begin by expanding $(a+10)(b+10)$ out: \begin{align*}
(a+10)(b+10) &= a(b+10) + 10(b+10) \\
&= ab+10a + 10b+100 \\
&= ab+10(a+b)+100.
\end{align*}This is congruent modulo $20$ to $ab+10(a+b)$.

Now we observe that $ab$ is $17$ more than a multiple of $20$, so $ab$ is odd, which means $a$ and $b$ must each be odd. Therefore, $a+b$ is even, so $10(a+b)$ is a multiple of $20$. It follows that $$ab+10(a+b) \equiv ab \equiv \boxed{17}\pmod{20}.$$

ground_truth:
We begin by expanding $(a+10)(b+10)$ out: \begin{align*}
(a+10)(b+10) &= a(b+10) + 10(b+10) \\
&= ab+10a + 10b+100 \\
&= ab+10(a+b)+100.
\end{align*}This is congruent modulo $20$ to $ab+10(a+b)$.

Now we observe that $ab$ is $17$ more than a multiple of $20$, so $ab$ is odd, which means $a$ and $b$ must each be odd. Therefore, $a+b$ is even, so $10(a+b)$ is a multiple of $20$. It follows that $$ab+10(a+b) \equiv ab \equiv \boxed{17}\pmod{20}.$$
